content.text: Place the metre rule on the pivot and adjust its position so that the metre rule is as near as possible to being balanced. The \(30.0 \text{cm}\) mark must be on the left-hand side of the pivot. **The metre rule must remain at this position on the pivot throughout the experiment.**
Place the load \(\mathbf{P}\) on the metre rule so that its centre is exactly at the \(30.0 \text{cm}\) mark on the metre rule
Record the distance \(a\) between the \(30.0 \text{cm}\) mark and the pivot
Measure the distance \(b\) between the centre of load \(\mathbf{Q}\) and the pivot. Record the weight \(Q\) and the distance \(b\) in Table 1.1

Repeat the procedure, with the load \(\mathbf{P}\) remaining at the \(30.0 \text{cm}\) mark, using \(Q\) values of \(2.0 \text{N}\), \(3.0 \text{N}\), \(4.0 \text{N}\) and \(5.0 \text{N}\). Record all the readings in the table
For each value of \(Q\), calculate \(\frac{1}{Q}\) and record the result in the table
Place a load \(\mathbf{Q}\) on the metre rule and adjust the position of \(\mathbf{Q}\) so that the metre rule is as near as possible to being balanced. Load \(\mathbf{Q}\) has a weight \(Q\) of 1.0N
Plot a graph of \(b / \text{cm}\) ( \(y\text{-axis}\) ) against \(\frac{1}{Q} /\frac{1}{N}\) ( \(x\text{-axis}\) )
Determine the gradient \(G\) of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
Calculate the weight \(P\) of load \(\mathbf{P}\) using the equation \(P = \frac{G}{a}\)
In this experiment, you will determine the weight of a load using a balancing method

Measure and record the potential difference \(V_{3}\) across the three resistors and the current \(I_{3}\) in the circuit
Switch off. Calculate the resistance \(R_{3}\) of resistors \(\mathbf{R_{A}}, \mathbf{R_{B}}\) and \(\mathbf{R_{C}}\) combined in series, using the equation \(R_{3} = \frac{V_{3}}{I_{3}}.\)

A student suggests that \(R_{3} = 3 \times R_{1}\)
State whether your results agree with this suggestion. Justify your answer by reference to your results

the three resistors connected in parallel
the voltmeter connected to measure the potential difference across the resistors
a variable resistor connected to control the current in all three resistors

The circuit shown in Fig. 2.1 has been set up for you
Place the centre of the lens at a distance \(u = 20.0 \text{cm}\) from the illuminated object
Place the screen close to the lens and move it away from the lens until a sharply-focused image is formed on the screen
Measure the distance \(v\) from the centre of the lens to the screen. Record \(v\) in Table 3.1
Calculate \(uv\) and record the result in the table
Measure and record in the table the distance \(D\) from the illuminated object to the screen
Repeat the steps in **(a)** with the lens at a distance \(u = 30.0 \text{cm}\) from the illuminated object. Record all the readings in the table
State one difference that you observe between the image formed on the screen when \(u = 20.0 \text{cm}\) and when \(u = 30.0 \text{cm}\)
